questions.text: Of the following statements regarding the division of labor on basis of dilatation and descent curves all are true except

choices.text: Preparatory division includes latent and acceleration phases
Dilatational division is unafected by sedation
Pelvic division encompasses both deceleration phase and second stage of labor

questions.solution:
Dilatational division occupies phase of maximum slope. The acceleration phase is included in preparatory division.

A scientific approach by Friedman (1954) described a characteristic sigmoid pattern for labor by graphing cervical dilatation against time.

Related Pearl: Functional divisions of labor

Preparatory division Dilatational division Pelvic division
Latent phase + acceleration phases The phase of maximum slope Deceleration phase + the second stage of labor

Little cervical dilatation

The most rapid rate of dilatation

 Cardinal fetal movements of cephalic presentation occur

Sedation and conduction analgesia can arrest this division

 Unaffected by sedation  --

questions.text:
The laparoscopy report of a woman with pelvic inflammatory disease states she has Gainesville stage III PID. Which of the following presentations could have been seen in her?
  1. Acute salpingitis with peritonitis.
  2. Acute salpingitis with no adhesions.
  3. Acute salpingitis with tubo-ovarian complex
  4. Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess
  5. Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion
questions.solution:
Gainesville stage III includes two forms of PID - acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex.

Gainesville has described the stages of PID depending upon the severity of tubal damage as follows:

Stage

Condition 

Stage I 

Acute salpingitis without peritonitis - no adhesions 

Stage II 

Acute salpingitis with peritonitis - purulent discharge  

Stage III

Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex 

Stage IV

Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess 

Stage V

Tubercular salpingitis

questions.text: Which among the following is not a feature of modified radical hysterectomy ?
questions.solution: • In modified radical hysterectomy (Type 2) upper 2cm of vagina is removed.

questions.text: A woman on post-natal day 1 presented with abdominal pain which worsens when she is breastfeeding. What is this known as?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of afterpains which are seen during puerperium.

In primiparous women, the uterus tends to remain tonically contracted following delivery. In multiparous women, it often contracts vigorously at intervals and gives rise to afterpains, which are similar to but milder than labor contractions.

These are more pronounced as parity increases and worsen when the infant suckles, likely because of oxytocin release. Afterpains gradually decrease in intensity and become mild by the third day.

questions.text: Dysfunctional uterine bleeding is defined as a state of abnormal uterine bleeding without any clinically detectable ______
questions.solution:
• DUB is defined as a state of abnormal uterine bleeding without any clinically detectable organic, systemic, and iatrogenic cause (Pelvic pathology, e.g., tumor, inflammation or pregnancy is excluded).
  • In this case, hormonal imbalance is considered the root cause of hyperplasia of the endometrium that causes menorrhagia; this often happens in anovulatory cycles with excessive or unopposed influence of oestrogen on the endometrium.

questions.text: Which of the following presentations is unlikely to be seen in a patient with gonorrhoea?
questions.solution:
Haematuria is unlikely to be seen in a patient with gonorrhoea.

Gynaecological presentation of gonorrhoea is:

  • Excessive vaginal discharge associated with pruritus and inflammation
  • Acute unilateral pain and swelling over labia due to the involvement of Bartholin’s gland
  • Intermenstrual bleeding

Non-gynaecological presentation of gonorrhoea is:

  • Pharyngeal infection
  • Dysuria 
  • Rectal discomfort due to associated proctitis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman at 14 weeks of gestation was rushed to the ER with complaints of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. USG showed an edematous right ovary with a large cyst and disruption in adnexal flow on Doppler. Which of the following most commonly leads to this condition?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of ovarian torsion. Mature cystic teratoma (dermoid cyst) is the commonest tumor to undergo torsion, especially at the end of the 1st trimester or during puerperium.

Management includes derotation and cystectomy in pregnancy irrespective of gestational age. This is also done in non-pregnant women of reproductive age to preserve ovarian function. Resection is reserved for patients in whom malignancy is suspected.

Dermoid cyst is the most common germ cell tumor. It is also the most common benign tumor of the ovary in the reproductive age group and in pregnancy. It is bilateral in 10-15% of cases. 

Dermoid cyst is derived from all three germ cell layers, but ectodermal derivatives are most common. Rokitansky’s protuberance is the most common site for the development of malignancy. It is seen as a projection covered by skin, sebaceous glands, sweat glands, teeth, and bones. Sometimes thyroid tissue can be seen on histopathological examination, known as struma ovarii.

The image below shows a dermoid cyst with Rokitansky protuberance.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive UPT. Her past obstetric history was significant for 2 mid-trimester abortions. On USG, cervical length was 20 mm and no bulging membranes were seen.  What is the next step in her management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cervical incompetence. It can be managed with prophylactic cervical cerclage done between 12 and 14 weeks of gestation.

Rescue or emergency cerclage is done anytime within 24 weeks of gestation. It should only be done when there is bulging of membranes through the dilated cervix. 

Investigations for cervical incompetence:

  • In interconceptional period - 
    • Passage of number 6 - 8 Hegar's dilator beyond the internal os without resistance or pain
    • Funnel-shaped shadow in premenstrual hysterocervicography
  • During pregnancy -
    • Per speculum examination showing cervical dilatation with herniation of membranes
    • USG revealing cervical length <2.5 cm and funnelling of internal os >1 cm

questions.text: A young girl with McCune-Albright syndrome is noted to have precocious menstruation. This condition is defined as the occurrence of menstruation at____.
questions.solution:
Precocious menstruation refers to the occurrence of menstruation before the age of 10 years. 

Precocious puberty in a girl is the appearance of any of the secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years or the occurrence of menarche before the age of 10 years.

McCune Albright syndrome is associated with cafe-au-lait spots, precocious puberty (and precocious menstruation), and polyostotic fibrous dysplasia leading to recurrent fractures. The image given below shows cafe-au-lait spots.

questions.text: A 25-year-old nulliparous woman presents to you with primary infertility. On examination, stage 2 uterine prolapse is present. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Sling operations are recommended in cases of nulliparous prolapse, who wish to retain menstrual and child-bearing function

Mackenrodt’s and uterosacral ligaments of the uterus are strengthened, by using nylon or Dacron tapes as slings. Abdominal sling operations include:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy - cervical supports are fixed to the abdominal wall
  • Shirodkar’s sling operation - cervix is fixed to the lumbosacral fascia using Mersilene tape
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation - isthmus of the cervix is fixed to the anterior superior iliac spines. It is not done anymore due to the risk of periosteitis. 
  • Virkud's sling operation - the tape is fixed from the isthmus and attached to the rectus compartment 
  • Joshi's sling operation - the uterus is suspended from the pectineal ligaments.

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Category Treatment
Nulliparous or congenital prolapse 

Abdominal sling operations:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation
Pregnancy and postnatal period
  • Ring pessary (up to 16 weeks period of gestation)
  • Pelvic floor exercises
<40 years            
  • Fothergill's repair (Manchester operation)
  • Shirodkar's procedure
>40 years - with completed family  Vaginal hysterectomy and pelvic floor repair 
>60 years - unfit for surgery 
  • Le Fort's repair
  • Colpocleisis

These are done if the patient doesn't want to retain sexual function

questions.text: Staging laparotomy was performed in a teenage girl who presented with an adnexal mass. Histopathological examination showed the following. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows Schiller-Duval bodies. It is suggestive of a yolk sac tumor (endodermal sinus tumor).

It is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. It occurs in ovaries or testes and sacrococcygeal areas in young children. It is usually unilateral. These tumors are usually associated with raised AFP and alpha 1 antitrypsin.

The image below depicts Schiller-Duval bodies. It consists of a central capillary surrounded by tumor cells, present within a cystic space that may be lined by flat to cuboidal tumor cells. 50% of yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic when present. 

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the resumption of meiosis-I?
questions.solution: Meiosis-I in the primary oocyte is resumed after LH surge.

questions.text: In a patient diagnosed with PCOS, which of the following is not an indication for surgical management?
questions.solution:
Surgical management is indicated in all the above conditions except for morbid obesity.

Indications of surgery in PCOS include:

  • Failed medical therapy
  • Ovarian hyperstimulation
  • Infertility
  • Previous pregnancy losses

Surgery comprises of laparoscopic drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. It is done using a laser or by unipolar electrocautery. It restores the endocrine milieu and improves fertility for a year or so. Thereafter, pelvic adhesions caused by surgery may again reduce the fertility rate. The formation of adhesions can be reduced by hydrofloatation.

The advantages of surgery are as follows: 

  • Tubal testing with chromotubation can be performed simultaneously
  • Other causes of infertility like endometriosis can be looked for
  • One-time treatment
  • Intense and prolonged monitoring for side effects is not required
  • Cost-effective compared to IVF
  • Reduces androgen and LH production
  • Following surgery, single ovulation occurs with drugs, and hyperstimulation and multiple pregnancies are avoided
  • Ovulation occurs in 80–90% and pregnancy in 60–70%

The disadvantages of surgery are as follows:

  • It involves giving anaesthesia and performing an invasive procedure like laparoscopy
  • Adhesions may form postoperatively
  • If cautery is used, premature ovarian failure due to destruction of ovarian tissue may be seen

questions.text: A 34-year-old G3P2L2 woman presents to the ER with hypotension, tachycardia, and severe abdominal pain. On examination, fetal parts are palpable in the abdomen. USG abdomen revealed a large uterine wall defect. What's the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of uterine rupture. The most common cause is scar dehiscence due to a previous cesarean section. This can occur due to trial of labour after C-section, or due to spontaneous labor in a patient with previous C-section. Other causes of uterine rupture are:

  • Prolonged induction or augmentation of labor
  • Obstructed labor
  • Blunt abdominal trauma during pregnancy
  • Rupture of hematometra
  • Rupture of pyometra 

 Uterine rupture is managed as follows:

  • Immediate cesarean section
  • Depending upon the extent of rupture:
    • Subtotal hysterectomy
    • Hysterectomy

questions.text: Which of the following is a prerequisite for internal rotation of the fetal head for a woman in labor?
questions.solution:
The tone of levator ani muscles is a prerequisite for internal rotation of the head.

Prerequisites of internal rotation of the head are as follows:

  • Well-flexed head
  • Efficient uterine contraction
  • Favorable shape at mid-pelvic plane
  • Tone of the levator ani muscles

questions.text: The USG below demonstrates
questions.solution:
Sonograms of hydatidiform moles

Complete mole:

  • The above image shows sagittal view of a uterus with a complete hydatidiform mole.
  • The characteristic “snowstorm” appearance is due to an echogenic uterine mass that has numerous anechoic cystic spaces but without a fetus and amnionic sac.

Partial mole:

  • A partial mole has features that include a thickened, multicystic placenta along with a fetus or at least fetal tissue.
  • Increase in the transverse diameter of the gestational sac
  • In early pregnancy, however, these sonographic characteristics are seen in fewer than half of hydatidiform moles.
  •  The most common misdiagnosis is incomplete or missed abortion.

Occasionally molar pregnancy can be confused for a multifetal pregnancy or a uterine leiomyoma with cystic degeneration.

questions.text: When does red degeneration of fibroids most commonly occur?
questions.solution:
Red/carneous degeneration occurs most commonly during the second trimester of pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: A P3L3 post-menopausal woman is diagnosed with type III genuine stress incontinence. Which of the following causes this condition?
questions.solution:
Type III genuine stress incontinence (GSI) is due to intrinsic sphincter deficiency.

Genuine stress incontinence is the involuntary leakage of urine due to increased abdominal pressure in the absence of contraction of the detrusor muscle. It occurs when physical stress causes the bladder pressure to exceed the urethral pressure.

GSI is classified into three types based on the mechanism of incontinence:

Type of GSI Mechanism of incontinence
Type I Loss of posterior urethrovesical angle
Type II

Loss of posterior urethrovesical angle

Urethral hypermobility
Type III Intrinsic sphincter deficiency 

Genuine stress incontinence (GSI) can further be graded into three different severities:

  • Grade 1 - Incontinence on severe stress, such as coughing, sneezing, or jogging
  • Grade 2 - Incontinence on moderate stress such as walking fast or climbing stairs
  • Grade 3 - Incontinence on mild stress, such as on standing

questions.text: T sign is seen in _______
questions.solution:
T sign is seen in a monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

It helps to differentiate between monochorionic and dichorionic pregnancies. While T sign is seen in monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy, Lambda sign is seen in dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

Monochorionic diamniotic pregnancies have a dividing membrane that is thin (less than 2 mm) and formed by amnions of each twin. A “T” is formed at the point at which amnions meet the placenta. It may not be seen until the second trimester.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about amniotic fluid?

choices.text: Major source is fetal urine after 20 weeks
It is primarily reabsorbed by fetal swallowing

questions.solution:
The composition of amniotic fluid is not the same throughout pregnancy but changes later in pregnancy due to contamination by fetal urinary metabolites.

In early pregnancy, it is identical to plasma in composition as it is mainly composed of a transudate of plasma. In late pregnancy, as amniotic fluid is primarily formed by fetal urination, the composition is altered. Disorders of the fetal kidney can lead to oligohydramnios.

Fetal swallowing is the primary method of resorption of amniotic fluid. Disorders of swallowing in the fetus can cause polyhydramnios.

Amniotic fluid is alkaline in nature and this helps in differentiating it from vaginal secretions which are acidic. This forms the basis of the nitrazine paper test used for the diagnosis of premature rupture of membranes.

questions.text: A diagnostic laparoscopy was performed on a 27-year-old woman with severe dysmenorrhoea and dyspareunia.  The following finding was seen on the pelvic peritoneum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the image showing characteristic powder burn spots seen over the pelvic peritoneum on laparoscopy point toward a diagnosis of pelvic endometriosis.

On laparoscopy, the typical endometriotic lesions appear like small black, dark brown or bluish dots. These are called powder burns or gunshot appearance of the serosal surfaces of the peritoneum. They are nodules or small cysts containing old haemorrhages surrounded by a variable degree of fibrosis.

Subtle appearances of endometriosis seen on laparoscopy are:

  • Red flame-shaped areas
  • Red polypoid areas
  • Yellow-brown patches
  • White peritoneal plaques or scarring
  • Peritoneal defects - known as Allen Masters Syndrome
  • Subovarian adhesions.

The lesions mentioned above are thought to be more active than the powder burn areas.

Endometriotic lesions in the peritoneal cavity contain yellowish-brown fluid. This fluid contains prostaglandins that are responsible for the pain associated with this condition. Endometriosis of the ovary leads to formation of the chocolate cyst which is a true cyst with columnar epithelium lining.

The image below shows the laparoscopic appearance of endometriotic lesions in the pouch of Douglas and on the right, the sacrouterine ligament. Dyspareunia occurs when the pouch of Douglas and rectovaginal septum are involved.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the Miller-Kurzrok test?

choices.text: Penetration of > 3 cm at 30 minutes is considered normal
Cervical mucus is placed alongside husband's semen on a glass slide
It is done at the time of ovulation
Jerky motility of sperm is considered normal

questions.solution:
In the Miller–Kurzrok test, sperm acquiring jerky motility after penetrating cervical mucus is considered abnormal.

The Miller-Kurzrok test is a special test done in semen analysis to diagnose the cause of infertility. It is an in vitro test of sperm–mucus interaction.

It is based on the basic principle that a normal cervical mucus permits invasion by motile sperms. It is done at the time of ovulation. The test consists of placing cervical mucus on a glass slide alongside the specimen of the husband's semen and studying the penetration of sperms under the microscope. The penetration of sperm > 3 cm into the mucus at 30 minutes is considered normal.

Other special tests in semen analysis include:

  • Sperm penetration test
  • Semen–cervical mucus contact test
  • Postcoital test (Sims’ or Huhner’s test)

questions.text: According to Priscilla White's classification for diabetes in pregnancy, all of the following classes should be managed with insulin except ______
questions.solution:
Class A1 is managed by diet therapy. Other than A1, all the other classes are managed by insulin therapy.

Priscilla White's classification for diabetes in pregnancy is not used anymore. It was modified by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists in 1986.

Class Description
Gestational Diabetes Mellitus
A1 Diet-controlled GDM
A2 Insulin-controlled GDM
Diabetes Mellitus
B Onset >20y
Duration <10y
C Onset 10-19y
Duration 10-19y
D Onset <10y
Duration >20y
Benign retinopathy
F Nephropathy
R Proliferative retinopathy
H Heart disease

Priscilla White was a pioneer in the treatment of diabetes complicating pregnancy. It emphasizes the importance of 3 factors such as the age of patient, duration of diabetes, and presence of vasculopathy.

questions.text: After how many weeks of postpartum will the uterus becomes a pelvic organ?
questions.solution:
The uterus becomes a pelvic organ by 2 weeks of postpartum.

Involution of the uterus occurs due to a decrease in the size of muscle fibers.

Time following delivery Features Weight of the uterus
Immediately following delivery

Uterus corresponds to 20 weeks gestational age

Fundus lies just below the umbilicus

 1000 g
48 hours  Myometrial involution starts  -
1 week Rapid involution of uterus 500 g
2 weeks The uterus becomes a pelvic organ 300 g
4 weeks Clinically, involution is complete 100 g
6-8 weeks

Uterus returns to normal (pre-pregnant) size

Sonographically, involution is complete at 8 weeks

 60 g

questions.text: An adolescent girl was brought by her mother to the clinic with complaints of irregular periods and acne. A USG scan was performed which showed the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the neck­lace appearance on ultrasound are suggestive of polycystic ovarian disease.

The original Rotterdam consensus defined polycystic ovaries when ≥12 follicles were seen per ovary on USG. Each follicle should measure between 2 and 9 mm, and/or an ovarian volume should be >10 ml. Due to improvement in imaging modalities since that time, the threshold for follicle number has now been raised to 20 per ovary.

questions.text: Radiotherapy is indicated in vulval cancer stage
questions.solution:
• Radiotherapy is indicated in stage 1 node +ve, 2 node +ve, 3 & 4

Related Pearl: Treatment Modality in Vulval Cancer

Stage Treatment
1A
  •  Radical wide local excision
     
1B
  • Partial vulvectomy + ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection
II
  • Tumor 2-4cm – total vulvectomy + B/L groin lymph node dissection
  • Tumor >4cm or poorly differentiated – radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
 
III
  • Megavoltage radiotherapy
  • Local surgical excision - Radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
  • Local recurrence – chemotherapy
 
IV
  • Chemotherapy or radiotherapy
  • Local excision on residual tumor
  • ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node + ve – contralateral node removed
  • Femoral lymph node +ve – pelvic lymph node removed

questions.text: During clinical pelvimetry, the obstetrician determines the diagonal conjugate to be X cm. What is the obstetric conjugate?
questions.solution:
The obstetric conjugate is X-2cm where X is the diagonal conjugate.

Anteroposterior diameters of the pelvis:

  • True conjugate or the anteroposterior diameter, extends from the upper most margin of the symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory. It is normally 11 cm.
  • Obstetrical conjugate is the shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis pubis. It is normally 10 cm. It is estimated indirectly by subtracting 1.5–2 cm from the diagonal conjugate.
  • Diagonal conjugate is determined by measuring the distance from the lowest margin of the symphysis to the sacral promontory. It is normally 12cm. It is measured clinically.

questions.text: A pregnant lady delivered her baby unattended while she was on the way to the hospital. While examining her, you note a perineal tear in which the anal sphincter is disrupted. This tear is classified as___.
questions.solution:
The perineal tears in which anal sphincter is disrupted are classified as third-degree perineal tear.

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman presented with heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea. You suspect a diagnosis of submucous uterine fibroids. Which of the following investigations will help you confirm this?
  1. Ultrasound 
  2. Saline infusion sonography 
  3. CT abdomen 
  4. Hysterosalpingography
  5. Colposcopy
questions.solution:
Investigations required to identify submucous fibroids include:

  • USG - most commonly done. Transvaginal USG is useful to assess the location, dimension, and associated adnexal pathology.
  • MRI gives better soft tissue details but is not routinely done
  • Saline infusion sonography and hysteroscopy - help to visualise submucous fibroid more clearly
  • Laparoscopy - If uterus <12 weeks size and associated pelvic pain and infertility and to detect pelvic endometriosis and tubal pathology.
  • Uterine curettage – A bump is felt in submucous fibroid during endometrial curettage. Dilatation and curettage is done in patients presenting with postmenopausal bleeding.
  • Hysterosalpingography – A filling defect is seen.

CT abdomen is not very useful for the identification of submucous fibroids. These cannot be visualised on colposcopy either.

The image below shows the ultrasonographic appearance of a submucous fibroid (asterisk):

 

The image given below shows hysteroscopic view of a submucous fibroid:

questions.text: What is the most common type of vaginal cancer likely to be seen in a woman with a history of intrauterine di-ethyl stilbesterol exposure?
questions.solution:
Clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina is commonly seen in adoloscent girls with a history of intrauterine DES exposure. 

It involves the upper third of the anterior vaginal wall. Radical hysterectomy, vaginectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy is the treatment of choice. 

The most common lesion due to DES exposure is vaginal adenosis and not clear cell adenocarcinoma. It is a benign condition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G3P2 woman was admitted to the ward at 40 weeks of gestation for induction of labor. You were asked to calculate her Bishop's score. What should be the minimum score before performing this procedure?
questions.solution:
The minimum Bishop Score required before proceeding with induction of labour is 6.

A Bishop score >8 conveys a high likelihood of a successful induction. The latest guidelines state that a cut-off score of 6 can be used to choose between pharmacological and mechanical methods of induction.

This score is calculated based on the:

  • station of the fetal head
  • dilation of cervix
  • cervical length
  • position of cervix
  • consistency of the cervix.

This score is an important determinant of a successful induction.

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with dyspareunia is diagnosed to have endometriosis. Which of the following drugs is not useful for her treatment?
questions.solution:
Estrogen is not used in the treatment of endometriosis as the condition is estrogen-dependent.

For minimal disease, the drug of choice is NSAIDs. Oral contraceptive pills are given if associated menstrual complaints are present. OCPs inhibit gonadotropin release and decrease the menstrual flow.

For moderate to severe disease, oral progestogens are the first drugs to be started. They are known to antagonize estrogenic effects on the endometrium causing endometrial atrophy. The drug of choice is GnRH agonists.

Note: The best time to conceive in a patient with endometriosis is immediately after surgery.

questions.text: Which among the following is the mainstay of treatment in a patient diagnosed with Stage III endometrial cancer?
questions.solution:
Chemotherapy is the mainstay of treatment in Stage III endometrial cancer.

In order to stage carcinoma endometrium, total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and lymphadenectomy is done (surgical staging). 

Thus the management, once staging is done, is mainly postoperative. Up to stage II, radiotherapy can be given. Stages III & IV are managed by chemotherapy such as doxorubicin, cisplatin, and paclitaxel.

Note: Stage III is said to be inoperable but debulking surgery is sometimes attempted. However, the mainstay of treatment for stage III disease remains chemotherapy.

Related Pearl: Management of endometrial cancer

Surgery is done for staging of the cancer. The surgery done for this purpose is abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, omentectomy, and pelvic as well as para-aortic lymph node sampling.

Stage Treatment
IA noninvasive 
  • Surgery alone
IA
  • Surgery
  • Post-op radiotherapy
IB
  • Surgery
  • Post-op pelvic radiotherapy 4000-5000 cGy
  • Post-op vaginal vault radiotherapy
II
  • Surgery
  • Post-op brachytherapy
  • Post-op external beam radiotherapy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
III
  • Inoperable/ Cytoreduction
  • Chemotherapy with Doxorubicin+Cisplatin+Paclitaxel
  • Medroxyprogesterone adjuvant
IV
  • Inoperable/ Cytoreduction
  • Palliative radiotherapy/chemo/ progesterone therapy

*This pearl is in line with the FIGO 2010 guidelines. It will be updated according to the FIGO 2023 guidelines after an official treatment guideline is released.

questions.text: Which of the following factors maximally increases the risk of tubal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Prior tubal surgery for ectopic pregnancy has the highest risk of tubal pregnancy among the given options.

Risk factors for ectopic pregnancy:

  • Prior ectopic pregnancy
  • Prior tubal surgery for ectopic, recanalization of tube post-sterilization
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease - most common cause for ectopic pregnancy
  • Infertility
  • Artificial reproductive therapy
  • Endometriosis
  • Smoking
  • Maternal age >40 years
  • Contraceptive methods - intrauterine device, progesterone-only pills

questions.text: Human placenta is best described as
questions.solution:
The human placenta is a discoid, deciduate, labyrinthine and hemochorial type.

Interpretation of the fine structure of the placenta by electron microscope shows prominent microvilli on the syncytial surface which help increase the surface area in direct contact with, maternal blood. The contact between the trophoblast and the maternal blood is the defining characteristic of a hemochorial placenta.

Placenta is discoid like in shape.

It is deciduate as it is shed at the time of parturition.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is used to take sample from _______
questions.solution:
The given image is of cytobrush – to take samples from endocervix.

(Ayre’s spatula – to take samples from squamocolumnar junction.)

Note:

For hormonal study, sample is taken from the lateral wall of vagina.

For cytological study, sample is taken from the posterior wall of vagina.

Ayre's spatula with a slide bottle.

questions.text: Abnormally high plasma hCG levels are found in all except
questions.solution:
In ectopic pregnancy, hCG levels are lower than normal.

Substantively high levels of hCG detected in:

  • Multiple pregnancy
  • Hydatidiform mole or choriocarcinoma and
  • Pregnancy with a trisomy 21 fetus (Down’s syndrome)
  • Erythroblastosis fetalis associated with fetal hemolytic anemia

Relatively lower levels of hCG detected in:

  • Ectopic pregnancies
  • Spontaneous abortion

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the pathogenesis of pre-eclampsia?

choices.text: Vascular sensitivity to angiotensin 2 is increased
There is an increase in sFlt -1 levels
A decrease in the level of soluble endoglin is seen

questions.solution:
In pre-eclampsia, there is an increase in the level of soluble endoglin.

Excessive amounts of antiangiogenic factors, increased sensitivity to angiotensin, and lowered angiotensinase levels worsen hypoxia at the uteroplacental interface.

Trophoblast of women who develop preeclampsia overproduces at least two antiangiogenic peptides that enter the maternal circulation. They increase months before clinical preeclampsia develops.

  • Soluble endoglin (sEng) is derived from the placenta and blocks endothelial nitric oxide-dependent vasodilatation. It also inhibits various TGFβ isoforms from binding to endothelial receptors.
  • Soluble Fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (sFlt-1) is a variant of the Flt-1 receptor for placental growth factor (PlGF) and for VEGF. Increased maternal sFlt-1 levels inactivate and decrease circulating free PlGF and VEGF concentrations, leading to endothelial dysfunction.

questions.text: Which of the following events in Rh-negative patients does not require Anti-D prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Postpartum hemorrhage is not an indication of Anti-D prophylaxis.

Anti-D prophylaxis is administered to Rh-negative patients in the following circumstances:

  • Pregnancy loss due to:
    • Ectopic pregnancy
    • Spontaneous abortion/hydatiform mole
    • Elective abortion
    • Fetal death (any trimester)
  • Procedures:
    • Amniocentesis
    • Chorionic villus sampling
    • Fetal blood sampling
    • External cephalic version
  • Delivery
  • Trauma
  • Placental abruption
  • Unexplained vaginal bleeding during pregnancy

questions.text: What is the normal pH of amniotic fluid?
questions.solution:
The normal pH of the amniotic fluid is 7.1 - 7.3

The normal pH of the vaginal secretions is 4.5 - 5.5. In premature rupture of membranes (PROM), the pH of the vaginal secretions becomes 6 - 6.2 as the amniotic fluid mixes with it. This forms the basis for nitrazine paper test.

questions.text: The most common chronic disease leading to anemia in pregnancy is ________
questions.solution:
Chronic renal insufficiency is the most common disorder encountered as a cause of anemia during pregnancy.

Recombinant erythropoietin is used in treating anaemia due to chronic renal failure.

questions.text: What does the term 'placental sign' denote?

choices.text: Alteration of fetal heart rate on pressing the head into the pelvis
Spotting on the expected date of period in early months of pregnancy
Permanent lengthening of the cord in 3rd stage of labor
Slight gush of bleeding in 3rd stage of labor

questions.solution:
Spotting on the expected date of menstruation in the early months of pregnancy is known as placental sign.

Cyclic bleeding may occur up to 12 weeks of pregnancy until the decidual space is obliterated by the fusion of decidua parietalis with decidua capsularis. The bleeding is usually scanty and lasts for a shorter duration than in a regular menstrual cycle.

Option A: Slowing of the fetal heart rate (FHR) on pressing the head down into the pelvis is suggestive of placenta previa (especially of posterior type) and is called Stallworthy’s sign. The fetal heart rate recovers as soon as the pressure is released.

Options C and D: Permanent lengthening of the cord and slight gush of bleeding in 3rd stage of labor are suggestive of separation of the placenta.

questions.text: Which finding is most likely to be seen in a patient with pre-eclampsia?
questions.solution:
Decreased GFR is seen in pre-eclampsia.

During normal pregnancy, renal blood flow and GFR are increased. However, in pre-eclampsia, renal blood flow and GFR decrease due to increased renal afferent arteriolar resistance. The hallmark renal lesion is glomerular endotheliosis. Diminished filtration causes serum creatinine levels and plasma uric acid concentration levels to rise. The elevation is also due to enhanced tubular reabsorption.

The most common system involved in pre-eclampsia is the renal system.

Several studies have demonstrated that pre-eclampsia is associated with low urinary calcium. This is often used as a predictive test.

questions.text: The following figure shows the transverse section of the uterus with an implanted zygote. Identify structure A.
questions.solution:
In the given image, the decidua basalis is marked as A. This part of the decidua forms the placenta.

Implantation occurs 6 to 7 days after fertilization. After implantation, the endometrium is called the decidua. It is of the following types:

  • Decidua basalis - present over chorion frondosum. Decidua basalis and chorion frondosum form the placenta. 
  • Decidua capsularis - present over abembryonic pole. 
  • Decidua parietalis - present on the opposite side of the uterus.

The villi cover the entire surface of the chorion during the early weeks. As the fetus grows, the villi on the embryonic pole continue to grow, giving rise to the chorion frondosum. At the abembryonic pole, the villi degenerate. By the third month, this side of the chorion becomes smooth, and is called the chorion laeve.

As the fetus grows, the chorion laeve comes into contact with the decidua parietalis on the opposite side of the uterus, and fusion occurs. Thus, the uterine lumen is obliterated. The amnion and chorion fuse, to form the amniochorionic membrane. Rupture of the amniochorionic membrane during labor is called 'breaking of waters'.

Note: Superfetation can theoretically occur till the time the uterine lumen is not obliterated.

questions.text: The anatomical classification of the pelvis based on shape was given by ______.
questions.solution:
The anatomical classification of the pelvis based on shape was given by Caldwell and Moloy.

The greatest transverse diameter of the pelvic inlet divides the pelvis into anterior and posterior segments. The shapes of these segments help classify the pelvis as follows:

  • Gynecoid
  • Anthropoid
  • Android
  • Platypelloid

The various differences between these types is summarised below:

  Gynecoid  Anthropoid  Android  Platypelloid 
Shape  Round  Anteroposteriorly oval  Triangular/ Heart-shaped  Transversely oval / Flat bowl shaped
Sacral angle >90°  >90° <90° >90°
Side walls  Straight or slightly divergent  Straight or divergent  Convergent  Divergent 
Ischial spines  Not prominent  Not prominent  Prominent  Not prominent 
Subpubic angle   Wide (85°)  Slightly narrow  Narrow  Very wide (>90°) 
Fetal Position 

Occipitolateral 

Oblique occipitoanterior 

Direct occipitoanterior

Occipitoposterior 

Occipitolateral

Oblique occipitoposterior 

 Occipitolateral 
Engaging diameter Transverse / oblique  Anteroposterior  Transverse / oblique  Transverse 
Delivery  No difficulty   Face-to-pubis - most common.

Deep transverse arrest is common.

Difficult delivery with an increased chance of perineal injuries 

 No difficulty 

Option B: McAfee and Johnson's regimen is for the conservative management of placenta previa.

Option C: Page's and Sher's classification system is used to grade abruptio placentae. 

Option D: Burns and Marshall maneuver is used in breech delivery.

questions.text: Suitable cases for expectant management in case of placenta previa include all except:
questions.solution:
The duration of pregnancy must be less than 37 weeks for expectant management which was advocated by McAfee and Johnson. 

The aim of conservative management is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity without compromising maternal health.

Prerequisites:

  • Availability of blood for transfusion 
  • Facilities for cesarean section available 

Selection of cases for expectant management for placenta previa: 

  1. Mother is hemodynamically stable (Hb >10 g% and/or hematocrit > 30%) 
  2. Duration of pregnancy <37 weeks 
  3. No active vaginal bleeding 
  4. Fetus normal on USG and reactive on CTG

Conduct of expectant treatment: 

  • Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity 
  • Bed rest or pelvic rest
  • Periodic monitoring of mother for bleeding pv
  • Fetal surveillance with USG  
  • Tocolytics if contractions are present
  • Anti-D to all Rh-negative (unsensitized) women.

questions.text: False regarding UTI in pregnancy

choices.text: It is higher in people with sickle cell trait
The most common organism responsible is klebsiella
If ASB is not treated 25% of them will develop symptomatic infection

questions.solution:
Asymptomatic bacteriuria:

  • Organisms that cause urinary infections are those from the normal perineal flora. the most common causative agent is E.coli
  • Prevalence during pregnancy: 2-7%
  • Prevalence depends on parity (more in higher parity), race, socioeconomic status (more in low SES)
  • More common in sickle cell anemia/trait, diabetics
  • Definition: Presence of persistent, actively multiplying bacteria in the urinary tract in asymptomatic women. Clean voided specimen >/= 105 organisms is diagnostic.
  • If not treated ~25% develop symptomatic infection during pregnancy

questions.text: Increased maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein is detected in a primigravida. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Repeat measurement of MSAFP at a later date

questions.solution:
The next best step is targeted sonography. Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) levels are only used as a screening test and must be followed by a diagnostic test.

Amniocentesis is a diagnostic test for amniotic fluid AFP measurement. It was once considered the standard for the diagnosis of open neural tube disorders but has been replaced in most centers by targeted sonography.

Defects in fetal integuments, such as ventral wall and neural tube defects, permit fetal AFP to leak into the amnionic fluid. This results in increased MSAFP levels. This is detected on screening performed from 15 to 20 weeks of gestation.

Conditions with elevated MSAFP:

  • Wrong gestational age
  • Neural tube defects
  • Multiple pregnancies
  • Renal anomalies

Conditions with decreased MSAFP:

  • Trisomies (Down's syndrome)
  • Gestational trophoblastic disease.

questions.text: True statement regarding Braxton-Hicks contraction is

choices.text: The contraction is frequent and painful
Intra uterine pressure remains above 8 mm Hg
It is not felt in abdominal pregnancy
Contractions cannot be felt during bimanual palpation

questions.solution:
In abdominal pregnancy, Braxton-Hicks contraction is not felt. Only felt in intrauterine pregnancy.

  • From the very early weeks of pregnancy, the uterus undergoes spontaneous contraction.
  • Can be felt during bimanual palpation in early weeks or during abdominal palpation when the uterus feels firmer at one moment and softer at another.
  • The contractions may be excited by rubbing the uterus.
  • The contractions are irregular, infrequent, spasmodic and painless without any effect on dilatation of the cervix.
  • The patient is not conscious about the contractions. 
  • Intrauterine pressure remains below 8 mm Hg.
  • Near term, the contractions become frequent with increase in intensity so as to produce some discomfort to the patient.
  • It merges with the painful uterine contractions of labor.

questions.text: Placental sign denotes

choices.text: Cyclical bleeding occurs up to 12 weeks of pregnancy
Irregular bleeding occurs up to 12 weeks of pregnancy
Cyclical bleeding occurs up to 18 weeks of pregnancy
Irregular bleeding occurs up to 18 weeks of pregnancy

questions.solution:
• Cyclic bleeding may occur up to 12 weeks of pregnancy, until the decidual space is obliterated by the fusion of decidua vera with decidua capsularis.
  • Bleeding is usually scanty, lasting for a shorter duration than her usual and roughly corresponds with the date of the expected period.
